text:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at NewsRx Policy
and Law Daily \-- Investigators discuss new findings in Nutritional and
Metabolic Diseases and Conditions - Diabetes Mellitus. According to news
reporting originating from New York City, New York, by NewsRx correspondents,
research stated, "To assess the long-term safety and efficacy of the Resolute
zotarolimus-eluting stent (R-ZES). The R-ZES has been associated with low
rates of adverse events over short-intermediate term follow-up."

Financial support for this research came from Medtronic.

Our news editors obtained a quote from the research from Columbia University,
"However, reliable assessment of the safety and efficacy of any implanted
device requires long-term evaluation. The RESOLUTE US trial was a prospective,
observational study conducted at 116 U.S. sites and enrolled patients with de
novo coronary lesions. Patients were followed clinically for 5 years with
independent event adjudication and data monitoring. A total of 1,402 patients
(1,573 lesions) were enrolled; 34% had diabetes mellitus and 75% had ACC type
B2/C lesions. The 5-year rate of target lesion failure (TLF) was 12.3%, target
lesion revascularization was 6.5%, target vessel myocardial infarction was
3.2%, and cardiac death was 4.1%. Dual antiplatelet therapy usage was 94% at 1
year and 47% at 5 years, with a 0.1% and 0.5% respective incidence of definite
or probable stent thrombosis. The 5-year rate of TLF was 16.9% among patients
with diabetes mellitus and 14.7% in patients with at least one small (<= 2.5
mm) vessel treated. Covariates independently associated with 5-year TLF in
multivariable analysis included diabetes mellitus (odds ratio [OR] 1.89, p<
.001), prior coronary artery bypass grafting (OR 2.28, p< .001), prior
myocardial infarction (OR 1.85, p = .002), and smaller reference vessel
diameter (OR 1.75, p = .004)."

According to the news editors, the research concluded: "Results from the fully
adjudicated and monitored RESOLUTE US trial demonstrate long-term 5-year
safety and efficacy of the R-ZES stent among a relatively low-risk population
of patients, including a 0.5% rate of stent thrombosis at 5 years."

For more information on this research see: Long-term (5-year) clinical
evaluation of the Resolute zotarolimus-eluting coronary stent: The RESOLUTE US
clinical trial. _Catheterization and Cardiovascular Interventions_ ,
2020;95(6):1067-1073. _Catheterization and Cardiovascular Interventions_ can
be contacted at: Wiley, 111 River St, Hoboken 07030-5774, NJ, USA. (Wiley-
Blackwell - <http://www.wiley.com/>; Catheterization and Cardiovascular
Interventions -
<http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/journal/10.1002/(ISSN)1522-726X>)

The news editors report that additional information may be obtained by
contacting M.B. Leon, Columbia University, New York-Presbyterian Hospital, Med
Ctr, New York, NY 10032, United States. Additional authors for this research
include A.J. Kirtane, A.C. Yeung, M. Ball, J. Carr, C. O'Shaughnessy, L. Mauri
and M. Liu.

The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is:
<https://doi.org/10.1002/ccd.28392>. This DOI is a link to an online
electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your
direct source for a journal article and its citation.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around
the world.)

title: Study Data from Columbia University Update Understanding of Diabetes Mellitus [Long-term (5-year) clinical evaluation of the Resolute zotarolimus-eluting coronary stent: The RESOLUTE US clinical trial]: Nutritional and Metabolic Diseases and Conditions - Diabetes Mellitus
html:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at NewsRx Policy and Law Daily -- Investigators discuss new findings in Nutritional and Metabolic Diseases and Conditions - Diabetes Mellitus. According to news reporting originating from New York City, New York, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, “To assess the long-term safety and efficacy of the Resolute zotarolimus-eluting stent (R-ZES). The R-ZES has been associated with low rates of adverse events over short-intermediate term follow-up.”

Financial support for this research came from Medtronic.

Our news editors obtained a quote from the research from Columbia University, “However, reliable assessment of the safety and efficacy of any implanted device requires long-term evaluation. The RESOLUTE US trial was a prospective, observational study conducted at 116 U.S. sites and enrolled patients with de novo coronary lesions. Patients were followed clinically for 5 years with independent event adjudication and data monitoring. A total of 1,402 patients (1,573 lesions) were enrolled; 34% had diabetes mellitus and 75% had ACC type B2/C lesions. The 5-year rate of target lesion failure (TLF) was 12.3%, target lesion revascularization was 6.5%, target vessel myocardial infarction was 3.2%, and cardiac death was 4.1%. Dual antiplatelet therapy usage was 94% at 1 year and 47% at 5 years, with a 0.1% and 0.5% respective incidence of definite or probable stent thrombosis. The 5-year rate of TLF was 16.9% among patients with diabetes mellitus and 14.7% in patients with at least one small (<= 2.5 mm) vessel treated. Covariates independently associated with 5-year TLF in multivariable analysis included diabetes mellitus (odds ratio [OR] 1.89, p< .001), prior coronary artery bypass grafting (OR 2.28, p< .001), prior myocardial infarction (OR 1.85, p = .002), and smaller reference vessel diameter (OR 1.75, p = .004).”

According to the news editors, the research concluded: “Results from the fully adjudicated and monitored RESOLUTE US trial demonstrate long-term 5-year safety and efficacy of the R-ZES stent among a relatively low-risk population of patients, including a 0.5% rate of stent thrombosis at 5 years.”

For more information on this research see: Long-term (5-year) clinical evaluation of the Resolute zotarolimus-eluting coronary stent: The RESOLUTE US clinical trial. Catheterization and Cardiovascular Interventions, 2020;95(6):1067-1073. Catheterization and Cardiovascular Interventions can be contacted at: Wiley, 111 River St, Hoboken 07030-5774, NJ, USA. (Wiley-Blackwell - http://www.wiley.com/; Catheterization and Cardiovascular Interventions - http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/journal/10.1002/(ISSN)1522-726X)

The news editors report that additional information may be obtained by contacting M.B. Leon, Columbia University, New York-Presbyterian Hospital, Med Ctr, New York, NY 10032, United States. Additional authors for this research include A.J. Kirtane, A.C. Yeung, M. Ball, J. Carr, C. O’Shaughnessy, L. Mauri and M. Liu.

The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is: https://doi.org/10.1002/ccd.28392. This DOI is a link to an online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your direct source for a journal article and its citation.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around the world.)
